urn:contentItem:5WC3-2S51-DY0W-40NX-00000-00Amazon Announces That Their Company Will Open Two New Headquarters, One In New York City And The Other In Northern Virginia, The Move Says It Will Bring 50,000 New High-Paying Jobs; Democratic Congresswoman-Elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Says The $1.5 Billion Tax Break For Amazon In New York Isn't Worth It; Death Toll In California's Deadliest Wildfire Continues To Rise And More Than 200 People Are Still Unaccounted For; Florida's Election Vote Recounts Are Still Ongoing, Along With The Two Candidates, Rick Scott And Bill Nelson Both Filing A Lawsuit; Arizona Has Declared Democrat Kyrsten Sinema As The Winner, And Representative Martha McSally Has Already Conceded Her Defeat; Palmer Luckey's Conservative Political Beliefs Has Him Being Fired From Facebook; A Five-Country International Committee Is Asking Mark Zuckerberg To Appear Before Them But He Is Declining The Invitation; U.S And China Trade Back In Communication On All Levels; Discussion By The Trump Team On Tariffs For European Car Makers; Trump Criticizes France And Europe For Not Paying Fair Share On NATO Defense2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:09:17ZLexisNexisAmazon Announces That Their Company Will Open Two New Headquarters, One In New York City And The Other In Northern Virginia, The Move Says It Will Bring 50,000 New High-Paying Jobs; Democratic Congresswoman-Elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Says The $1.5 Billion Tax Break For Amazon In New York Isn't Worth It; Death Toll In California's Deadliest Wildfire Continues To Rise And More Than 200 People Are Still Unaccounted For; Florida's Election Vote Recounts Are Still Ongoing, Along With The Two Candidates, Rick Scott And Bill Nelson Both Filing A Lawsuit; Arizona Has Declared Democrat Kyrsten Sinema As The Winner, And Representative Martha McSally Has Already Conceded Her Defeat; Palmer Luckey's Conservative Political Beliefs Has Him Being Fired From Facebook; A Five-Country International Committee Is Asking Mark Zuckerberg To Appear Before Them But He Is Declining The Invitation; U.S And China Trade Back In Communication On All Levels; Discussion By The Trump Team On Tariffs For European Car Makers; Trump Criticizes France And Europe For Not Paying Fair Share On NATO DefenseLanhamFULL TEXT

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: And Bart knows it very well, backbone. And I don't think anybody will ever be able to fight it. That does it for Bulls and Bears. Thanks for joining us. "EVENING EDIT" starts now.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Amazon Prime for a major east coast move. The online retail giant announcing today it will open not one but two new headquarters, New York and Northern Virginia. A move Amazon says will create 50,000 new and high paying jobs but there are some big reasons why not everyone is happy.

Also, tonight in California, the wildfires there continue to rage. One of the now deadliest ever in that state. We'll bring you the latest from the ground.

Plus, Florida, the recount resumes as the deadline to certify a few statewide contests moves closer.

Republicans trying to flip a Senate seat there after Democrats put an Arizona seat in their win column.

Thank you for joining us tonight. I'm Blake Burman in for Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

The move so many have been waiting for but with a little bit of a twist today. Amazon announcing that they will open two new headquarters. One in New York City the other in Northern Virginia.

Deirdre Bolton has the very latest this evening. Hi, Deirdre.

(CROSSTALK)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Blake. Hi. So, this was a long-awaited decision, right, the company choosing Long Island City in Queens, New York, and then the other one in Crystal City area in Arlington, Virginia. So, these two locations chosen after more than a years' long public contest that began with 238 candidate cities.

So, Amazon saying it's going to be investing $5 billion across the two new areas. It's also going to be creating a new operation center in Nashville so completely separate with more than 5000 jobs.

The e-commerce giant saying it went for a split location because it wanted to recruit enough of the best tech talent. Now as part of the contract between Amazon and the two cities they are required to assist Amazon in obtaining a federal approval to build helipad at each location.

Skeptics say those are probably for Amazon's top execs to get in and out of both locations without being slow down by traffic but nonetheless that is part of the deal.

For that reason alone, some locals from some of the other cities that didn't get the nod actually seemed relieved that they took to social media. Comparing notes on the effect that Amazon's main HQ has had on Seattle. Locals of course there complain about skyrocketing rents, prolonged construction and gridlocked traffic.

Other smaller cities have locals that felt burned, in part because local officials had released so much data about their communities to the e- commerce giant.

Even with the recent decline for most tech stocks I want to highlight Amazon still up 40 percent year to date. The NASDAQ up around 4 percent as a comparison point. S&P 500 1.8 percent.

So, Blake, no matter what Amazon is doing year-to-date still a pretty good investment. Back to you.

BURMAN: Yes, one of the best stocks out there, indeed. Deirdre, thank you.

BOLTON: Sure.

BURMAN: Make sure to catch Deirdre's special by the way, Women and Money. It is this Friday at 9.30 Eastern here on the Fox Business Network.

Amazon says that this is a winner. Here's the company's breakdown. It says Virginia stand to receive some $3.2 billion in tax revenue over the next 20 years, with workers averaging over $150,000 a year. Virginia will give Amazon it says $573 million in brakes, 550 million about a cash grant, $23 million comes from the city of Arlington over 15 years for infrastructure projects and the like.

And New York will get $10 billion in tax revenue over the next two decades. So, says Amazon. Again, an average salary of more than $150,000. New York it says will give 1.525 billion in performance-based incentives. Now that's a $1.2 billion refundable tax credit and a cash grant of 325 million for buildings being occupied over the next 10 years so long as they hit those targets.

Not everyone is thrilled with this, as they say there is much more beyond the numbers.

David Dworkin is with the National Housing Conference. He is the CEO of that network and he joins us here in studio. Thanks for joining us.

DAVID DWORKIN, CEO, NATIONAL HOUSING CONFERENCE: Thanks, Blake. Good to be here.

BURMAN: So, when you talk about 25,000 jobs in each one of these major cities each person getting at least $150,000 a year in salary. Some would say what's wrong with that.

DWORKIN: There's nothing wrong with that. It's great news for both communities. The trick is, it needs to stay great news. And the problem that we have to deal with is that when you put that many people into a community at one time over a short period of time you are going to see housing prices go up both for renters and for homebuyers.

And if Amazon's employees can't afford to buy and rent in this community, they are going to end up with the same problem they had in Seattle and they don't want that either.

BURMAN: Deirdre just talked about that. I wanted to get to that in a second. Twenty-five thousand in each city. It's not like all 25,000 are suddenly going to emerge in both of these regions. Some will be from this area. How many do you expect in this greater Washington area and in New York City to suddenly show up there needing a place to live?

DWORKIN: Well, it could be a lot. And it's also already having an impact on pricing. You're seeing condos that were on the market just a few weeks ago. Not getting much action being bid up today and the same things is going to be the case in a little longer time frames with rental properties.

We want to make sure that the development doesn't lead to dislocation. We want people who live in these communities to be able to benefit from this new investment too.

BURMAN: You bring up Seattle. Sky price -- sky -- houses there have skyrocketed. This, speaking of Washington, D.C., has been one of the more stable markets. When it blooms, it doesn't bloom that much, and when it bust, it doesn't bust that much.

This market right here in Northern Virginia, in D.C., Maryland, do you think we could potentially be Seattle part two or three even if you bring New York into the equation?

DWORKIN: Well, we will be if we do it wrong. And the name of the game as we need to be very thoughtful about how we do this development, we need to make sure that we have housing for all incomes because it's all connected.

When housing prices are too high to buy, people rent. If you've got more people renting, rents are going to go up. So, they're all very interconnected. And you know, in Seattle, you have enormously high housing prices. You also have in the last four years, homelessness has doubled.

BURMAN: Last question for you. When you talk about Seattle or D.C. or New York City, in Northern Virginia it's Northern Virginia, D.C., Maryland and New York. You are talking about, also potentially out east onto Long Island, out West into New Jersey. How far, when you talk about housing, does this is actually spent even though the headquarters are going to be in a handful or doesn't full work a bit.

DWORKIN: Well, you know, when I bought my first house, I bought 20 miles outside of the city so that I could afford it. So, I think it's going to be pretty far and it's going to have an impact everywhere in the area.

BURMAN: David Dworkin, we will see what happens here, I guess this is day one of a long process moving forward.

DWORKIN: It is, indeed.

BURMAN: We'll see how it unfolds. Thanks, David. I appreciate it.

DWORKIN: Thanks for having me.

BURMAN: The newly elected Democratic Congresswoman Alexandria Ocasio- Cortez by the way, says the $1.5 billion tax break for Long Island silly, in New York, city, rather, in New York isn't worth it.

Here is one tweet she sent out just yesterday, saying, quote, "Amazon is a billion-dollar company. The idea that it will receive hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks at the time when our subway is crumbling and our communities need more investment not less, is extremely concerning to residents here."

Joining me now the former D.C. Chamber of Commerce chair Scott Bolden, and American Majority CEO Ned Ryun. Good evening to you both.

SCOTT BOLDEN, FORMER CHAIR, D.C. CHAMBER OF COMMERCE: Good evening.

NED RYUN, FOUNDER & CEO, AMERICAN MAJORITY: Good to be with you, Blake.

BURMAN: Ned, let's start there. Does the congresswoman elect have a point?

RYUN: Well, I got to tell you, Blake, I was reminded looking at those tweets. You know, back in the day the occupy movement the Tea party movement agreed on basically just one thing, how much low and despised corporate cronyism.

And when you see Amazon getting multi-billion-dollar tax incentives for not a billion-dollar company, a $1 trillion company, I got to tell you, my libertarian streak does not find that -- it doesn't sit well with me.

But I got to tell you, Blake, I'm not sure that was their biggest coup, because as Deirdre mentioned those 238 cities and regions in North America they gave Amazon all of their future infrastructure plans and land-use plans.

(CROSSTALK)

BURMAN: Amazon did--

RYUN: The incredible amount of data and power that Amazon has now I'm stunned.

BURMAN: That's one of the arguments that some folks put out there in the bidding process. Scott, do you think this really was a bidding process or do you think at the end of the day Jeff Bezos and Amazon said, you know, New York, it's got Wall Street, financial capital of the world, D.C., the political capital of the world, let's go there.

BOLDEN: Right. I don't think, I don't have any reason to believe that it wasn't a bidding process and those 238 cities can certainly get their data back. Well, they should have negotiated to get their data back. But they are less, right. If you don't give a million dollars or nine plus to a billion dollars in tax breaks for companies they'll go elsewhere.

And look at the trade-off. This is a deal. Forgive the term the art of the deal. They are going to get a billion dollars in tax breaks, they are going to invest $5 billion or more in Crystal City.

And with that 5 billion we are going to have transportation upgrades, housing development, airport upgrades, and the national landing at least of in Crystal City is going to be a tremendous drop point not only for other companies who could do the same in a smaller lever but also these 25,000 jobs at $150,000 a pop.

I got to tell you, this isn't a transformational boon for just Crystal City in Northern Virginia, this is a region, the fourth largest business region in the country. So, Maryland and D.C. are celebrating this. And if it's a housing issue and to do it right.

Listen, we got stable markets. People, 50 percent of the people who were in D.C. on a daily basis live in Virginia or Maryland. And so, we got a wide swap of ability to house 25,000 or more.

BURMAN: Ned--

(CROSSTALK)

BOLDEN: And so, whatever the downside is there's a huge upside and you can't ignore that.

BURMAN: Ned, in 10 seconds, how can you argue against 50,000 jobs at a 150k a pop.

RYUN: I believe some of this in reinvestment back into our communities. When I see it, I got to tell you, Blake, right now D.C. is one of the worst traffic cities. We have a real problem with our infrastructure. We have literally a web site to see if our metro is on fire on any given day.

I believe it when I see it. I would much rather they were given a 30 percent corporate tax break the local businesses instead of giving this massive one to Amazon.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLDEN: Hey, have us back.

BURMAN: Scott and Ned, we're going to have to--

(CROSSTALK)

BOLDEN: Have us back in a year or two.

BURMAN: We will have you back in a year or two. We'll leave it there. By the way, the metro here in D.C. say today six stations closed next summer. We'll see what happens.

Thank you to you both. We should note that Fox Business has reached out multiple times today for the Congresswoman-elect Ocasio-Cortez to appear on the network to discuss Amazon. She has yet to respond to our request.

Coming up, Facebook now in the crosshairs, I guess you could say once again, as the billionaire Mark Zuckerberg now declining to appear before an international grant committee as it's called, investigating the tech giant for election meddling. We'll explain why.

But first, the latest on those deadly California wildfires. Stay with us.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We mourn the lives of those lost. And we pray for the victims. There are more victims than anybody would ever even think possible.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: In my 35 years I've not seen as bad as this. In (Inaudible) town where the whole town is devastated.

I have family up here in the past and some family friends, and everything is gone. You know, almost every home is just -- the whole town was devastating.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Scenes like that all across California the death toll climbing in that state to 44 now. More than 200 people still remain unaccounted for and more than 7,000 structures there destroyed.

President Trump approving a major disaster declaration for that state.

With the latest now in the Fox weather center is Adam Klotz. Of course, one of one big question going forward are the conditions there throughout that state, what are we looking at here over the next few hours.

ADAM KLOTZ, FOX NEWS CHANNEL METEOROLOGIST: Well, things have improved slightly in Northern California but Southern California unfortunately continues to just be a really rough shape. The winds are strong, the humidity levels still very dry and no rain anywhere on the horizon.

So still high fire danger. This is the only part still left in the state for now, but you're stretching from San Diego back up to L.A. getting over towards the Woolsey Fire and some of those fires have been popping up just north of Los Angeles.

The conditions are still there, at least for the next couple of hours where that's going to be a problem. We got wind advisories in place throughout this entire region, but this is going to start to back down a little bit. These are just in place until 5 p.m. Pacific Time, which gives us about another hour and 45 minutes.

And we've already began to see these winds back down a little bit from gust to 70 miles an hour. Some of our current wind speeds getting here only into the teens, in some cases up to the 20s, but that is a substantial backing down of what we've seen in the last couple of days. So, perhaps giving some firefighters a chance to get in there.

The winds do not stop them. And this doesn't mean that it's over. It just means they've calmed down from some of the 70-mile hour winds. These are forecast wind gust, and typically we were seeing some getting up into those purple shades where it is closer to 70 miles an hour.

So now into the blue, so pretty consistently throughout the night tonight heading into tomorrow closer to 15 to 20 to 30 mile an hour winds which is a big step down for your Wednesday. That is going to be lingering here.

If there's any problem left its unfortunately that things are still so dry that even those 20 to 30-mile an hour winds even though they're not as bad may still be a problem. This is our relative humidity and you start to see some of these brown colors, Blake. Ten percent humidity, it is bone dry across Southern California and that is going to be sticking with us throughout the week ahead unfortunately.

BURMAN: And Adam, real quick, when you talk about how dry it is, any rain in the forecast coming up over the next few days or no?

KLOTZ: I do have a quick 60-hour forecast. And unfortunately, as you can tell some rain up in the Pacific Northwest but nothing that's going to be reaching some of these affected areas in California.

BURMAN: Well, all right. Adam Klotz tonight in the Fox weather center. Adam, thank you.

Joining me now is the Agoura Hills, California Mayor, Bill Koehler. Mr. Mayor, can you hear us tonight?

MAYOR WILLIAM KOEHLER, AGOURA HILLS, CALIFORNIA: Yes. Again, good afternoon.

BURMAN: Thank you for -- thank -- good afternoon to you. Thank you for joining us. Agoura Hills for the folks who don't know, you got the 101 freeway that cuts through California there east to west. You got Thousand Oaks and Westlake Village on one side, Calabasas, on the other, you're kind of in the middle there.

The conditions that you're seeing right now in your community are what?

KOEHLER: Well, the conditions in our community have improved greatly over the last day the day and a half. The north side of the U.S. 101 freeway is now open. And one of our main arteries other than the 101 Agoura road has now open.

The south side of the freeway however, in the area of Liberty Canyon where the fire jumped the U.S. 101 on Friday morning is still closed.

BURMAN: You know, I was reading about your community earlier today and how you're helping out the firefighters there, giving them free meals, trying to do whatever you can to be an asset as they are battling one fire after the next hour after hour.

The stories of humanity always shine through when we have natural disasters like this. Tell me exactly what you're trying to do at this hour to help those who are battling these fires.

KOEHLER: Well, first of all, I'm very, very proud of the citizens of our community. It really stepped up and embraced the first responders, both fire and police services.

The other night I have stopped in at fire station 89, which is in the heart of Agoura Hills and talk to the firefighters as to what their experience is who were out in line in the communities.

And every single one of them were praising the citizens as to the people bringing them food, kind words, anything that they could do to assist to try to stay out of the way of the firefighters. And they were all extremely impressed by the outpouring of love, if not, in other words, for the first responders.

BURMAN: You obviously can't control the weather. Beyond that, what do you need most now?

KOEHLER: Well, rain what has been number one. But what we need is the cooperation of the citizens to be vigilant in watching the condition because they do change based upon wind and wind direction. And there are instances where what we called pop ups have occurred where ambers will be re-disturb and will blaze a new causing another fire incident.

And we want to make certain that we become aware of those right away so the fire department can extinguish down so that they don't grow.

BURMAN: Bill Koehler, the mayor of Agoura Hills, California, southern part of California there. Thank you for joining us this evening. Best of luck with everything out there, sir.

KOEHLER: Thank you. It's my pleasure.

BURMAN: We'll be right back. Stay with us. More Evening Edit coming up.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BURMAN: Welcome back. The route for oil continuing. Oil tumbling seven percent today and taking the energy sector right down with it. Twenty-seven of 29 energy stocks in the S&P 500 traded down. As for oil, it was the biggest sell-off in more than three years after President Trump called on OPEC to not cut output.

Meantime, tonight, Arizona and Florida and the Senate races there. One Senate seat flipped while the battle for another remains under recount. We have every angle covered this evening.

Phil Keating is live in Lauderhill, Florida, and Alicia Acuna is on the ground in Phoenix, Arizona. We begin with Phil in Florida where the recount deadline is looming for the Senate and governor's mansion there. Hi, Phil.

PHIL KEATING, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Blake. New lawsuits continue to fly here in Florida and a dramatic courtroom ruling by a circuit judge in Leon County giving Palm Beach County five extra days to complete their machine.

And Florida Democratic Senator Nelson's campaign also filed a new suit in federal court to have the Thursday 3 p.m. recount deadline voided so that every legal vote gets counted and recounted. Period. Deadline or not.

Senator Nelson currently trails Governor Scott by 12,000 votes.

You're looking live inside the Brown County recount room. The sorting of ballots has resumed. Broward County today completed recounting and tabulating all 300,000 of the early votes. An official say they are now ahead of schedule and confident they will meet the looming deadline of 3 p.m. Thursday.

Also today, beleaguered superintendent of elections, Brenda Snipes, spoke briefly, cameras were there. There has been much criticism of her office calls for her to resign. And today she indicated that could happen once this recount is over.

Senator Nelson joins Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer today in Washington.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SEN. BILL NELSON, (D) FLORIDA: This process is about one thing. Making sure that every legal ballot is counted and protecting the right of every Floridian to participate in our democracy.

Sadly, it's become clear that my opponent isn't interested in making sure that every lawful vote is counted.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

KEATING: And Presidents Trump still jumping into the Florida fray via twitter. "When will Bill Nelson concede in Florida? The characters running Broward and Palm Beach voting will not be able to find enough votes, too much spotlight on them now."

Statewide several counties have already completed their machine recounts, they are going to make that Thursday afternoon deadline. Meanwhile, in the most densely populated counties in Florida, there's Palm Beach, Broward, and Miami-Dade the counting and recounting continues 24 hours a day. Blake?

BURMAN: Phil Keating live in Broward County, Florida tonight. Phil, thanks. And to Arizona now where the Democrat Kyrsten Sinema defeated her Republican opponent, Martha McSally, flipping a seat that has been in GOP hands for 24 years.

Alicia Acuna has the details. Alicia?

ALICIA ACUNA, FOX NEWS CHANNEL REPORTER: Hi, Blake. As the senator-elect was back on Capitol Hill today, she was there to place votes as a role as a member of a current member of the House, but she was also there for Senate orientation.

And Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer tweeted a picture with Kyrsten Sinema, writing, "As the votes, women of the West -- excuse me -- two new great women Democratic senators from the western part of the United States, Kyrsten Sinema from Arizona, and Jackie Rosen from Nevada. So proud we'll be working with them in January."

As the votes continue to be counted, the Associated Press projected Sinema the winner last night after she pulled ahead in the tally by 38,000. Not long after she appeared before supporters in Scottsdale.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. KYRSTEN SINEMA, (D) ARIZONA: Arizona rejected what has become far too common in our country. Name-calling, petty personal attacks and doing and saying whatever it takes just to get elected. It's dangerous. And it lessens who we are as a country.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ACUNA: Republican Congresswoman Martha McSally tweeted a concession video yesterday evening after calling her opponent to offer congratulations.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. MARTHA MCSALLY, (R) ARIZONA: I also want to say thank you to everybody who supported me in this campaign. My staff and volunteers and everybody who voted for me. I'm so grateful for you as my wingman, and wingmen in this journey. We sure wish it came out with a different resolve, but I'm so thankful for you.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ACUNA: This was not the anticipated outcome by Republicans in this red state. McSally lost Maricopa County, the largest county in the state and a traditional Republican stronghold. Demographics are changing here but McSally also closely aligned herself with the president and his hard line on immigration. Voters here had told people who are polling them that their number one issue was healthcare, Blake.

BURMAN: Alicia Acuna live tonight in Phoenix, Arizona. Alicia, thanks. Coming up, the U.S.-China trade talks revived ahead of President Trump's meeting coming up later this month. But President Xi of China will break it all down. But first, lawmakers from five countries pressuring Mark Zuckerberg to testify. Why the CEO has other plans.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BURMAN: Facebook quietly asked the Oculus founder, Palmer Luckey, back in 2016. And now the "Wall Street Journal" says it was likely over his conservative political views. Fox Business News Susan Li is in Laguna Beach with the very latest. Hi, Susan.

SUSAN LI, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Hi Blake. Yes. Palmer Luckey, one of the more colorful attendees here at the Wall Street Journal D Live Conference, and he was on a panel on Sunday and of course was asked about his departure at Facebook which he didn't directly address but take a listen.

(BEGIUN VIDEO CLIP)

PALMER LuCKEY, FOUNDER, OCULUS: I think it's dangerous where we see it going in the tech industry where you are seeing the polarization between political parties, making people disagree on things that should be bipartisan. People should agree that national security is important. But it's becoming for many people some kind of partisan issue.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: OK, so, also she point out that Palmer, his new venture is Anduril Technology where he is using technology to help police the U.S. borders. And he made a controversial comment in regards to Google and their employees petitioning to pull one of their contracts with the Pentagon, watch.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LUCKEY: It's worth noting, I don't mean to say in kind of xenophobic way, but it's worth noting that Google is -- a very large percentage of Google employees are not even U.S. citizens. A large number of those people that signed that petition saying don't work with the U.S. military, they weren't U.S. citizens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

LI: Yes. So, I tweeted that out and I got some pick-up and then Palmer came up to me at this event to clarify his statements. And he says what he was trying to say was that it's not surprising that somebody that doesn't live in the U.S., isn't a U.S. citizen, probably doesn't want U.S. military to have the best technology.

That didn't alleviate a lot of the criticism on twitter. Now, one thing Blake I want to tell you is that I feel like I drew the short straw today. I will take one for the team here in Laguna Beach. But next time it's on you.

BURMAN: I know you love New York. I'm sure you do.

LI: I know.

BURMAN: But Laguna Beach, it doesn't look bad, Susan.

LI: No, no, no, not at all.

BURMAN: Enjoy it out there. Stay out there for Thanksgiving, maybe Christmas too, whatever you want.

LI: Thank you.

BURMAN: Come back whenever. Susan Li, thank you. Appreciate it. Also tonight, the Facebook founder and CEO Mark Zuckerberg declining an invitation to appear before an international grand committee of at least five governments investigating the social media company for disinformation and election meddling. That is according to a report from CBS news.

Let's take it up with our panel now. Republican strategist Ford O'Connell and Democratic strategist Wendy Osefo. Thanks both for being here.

FORD O'CONNELL, REPUBLICAN STRATEGIST: Good to be here, Blake.

BURMAN: So, Wendy, let's start with you.

WENDY OSEFO, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: Yes.

BURMAN: Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook, other governments want him to show up, testify like he did here in Washington and Facebook is essentially saying hey, he can't go all around the world to do this. Do they have a point?

OSEFO: They have a point because he cannot go all around the world to do this but he has to show up. Time and time again Facebook is continuously under the radar for doing things that people are starting to question, even as of the midterm elections, they found that a lot of Russian bots where there trying to propel different types of narratives.

And as someone who has been on the receiving end of this, I had a post where I was talking about white supremacy and I wasn't saying it to support it but rather to point it out. Facebook and Instagram took down the post. So they need to decide what is bad language or what is good language and are they targeting and who are they not targeting.

O'CONNELL: To your point, Zuckerberg has no interest in attending this five-country confab on November 27th in London because he doesn't want to give them any more ammo for global regulators to come down on the tech giant. Look, earlier this year they passed a law over data breaches which actually has Facebook on the hook for $1.63 billion potentially.

And essentially, the U.S. regulators, basically the FTC, DOJ Anti-Trust division is looking at how the rest of the world is reacting to Facebook in terms of looking at data breaches, bias, misuse of information, disinformation to figure out how they can -- tailor something more narrow.

BURMAN: You talk about regulation. There is going to be a different make up on Capitol Hill in a couple of months.

OSEFO: Yes.

BURMAN: We saw Republicans want to hear from Mark Zuckerberg, want to hear from Jack Dorsey, hear from the tech community. What do you expect Democrats to do now that they have the ability to potentially call these folks up to the Hill?

OSEFO: I expect Democrats to do the exact same thing except this time I think that they are actually going to put a tighter foot on his neck so to speak because we all know that 2020 is coming up. We know that both parties have a lot to lose here.

They want to make sure that what's coming out of our internet where a lot of people find their information. Studies found that 70 percent of millennials finds their information from Facebook. So, we want to make sure that what's going on those platforms are actually correct.

O'CONNELL: It's even bigger than that, 68 percent of U.S. adults use it, 50 percent get their news from it. Look, I don't think there is the appetite on Capitol Hill. I do agree that Democrats are more interested in regulating it, but we just don't have the media outrage yet and the folks really on the same page and understanding that when it comes to big tech, this is worse than the CIA. They control how you think, how you vote, whether or not you recognize it.

OSEFO: Absolutely.

BURMAN: You talk about how, I mean, isn't the reality though, whether there is outrage or not, it's the Democrats who are going to have control as to whether or not Zuckerberg and Silicone Valley and those folks will come up or not.

OSEFO: And there is outrage. There is outrage.

O'CONNELL: There is outrage but it's selective. It's not yet where it is in the E.U. and the rest of the world. And all I'm going to say is, yes, the Democrats are going to bring him forward, but are we going to get some sort of legislation that's going to hold these folks in check? I don't believe that at this moment.

OSEFO: And we can get legislation to hold these folks in check if we start working where it hurts their pockets. And that's what we have not done. We need to hit them where it hurts their pockets. Right now there is no checks and balances. If he does this, what does he say? Oh, you can't do this again, nothing.

O'CONNELL: Well, my only concern is I'm not big on regulation, but I do believe that big tech is way out over its skis (ph) and really need to be put in its place. The only question is how we are going to do it. And remember, my guys still control the United States Senate.

So, finding that right balance if you want to get there, is going to be very hard to do. And remember, Donald trump doesn't have it out for Facebook, he has it out for Amazon.

BURMAN: And he has it out for over regulation though.

O'CONNELL: That is so true.

BURMAN: So there is that balance that this administration is dealing with on this because they say pull off regulation, pull off regulation, pull off regulations, but then many Republicans are saying, hey, we need to take a look at regulations in this industry.

O'CONNELL: I think that that is exactly right. The question here is when I look at U.S. regulators, OK, and what they are going to bring forth to Congress. What I look at is they're looking at what the E.U. is doing and they are saying how do I get a more narrowly tailored bill such that I cannot hurt business and U.S. companies but also keep them in check in terms of privacy and personal data.

OSEFO: But I think that that's the issue. I think the issues we are so focused on hurting business. We heed to make sure that whatever information is put out into the stratosphere, it's not hurting the American people and that should be the focus not big business.

O'CONNELL: I agree with you, the only question is how.

BURMAN: You know, it's a big issue because we just talked about Facebook and didn't mention Twitter, Google and the rest down the line. You can talk about this for hours into days. We're out of time. Wendy Osefo, Ford O'Connell, thank you very much.

O'CONNELL: Thank you, Blake.

OSEFO: Thank you.

BURMAN: We've got coming up, China, tariffs and trade back in the focus of the White House, the president, this administration. Big meeting up there today at the White House. We have details coming up after the break.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BURMAN: President Trump's top economic adviser Larry Kudlow is saying today the dialogue between the United States and China on trade is improving. This is the president's trade team discusses potential tariffs on European automakers. Fox Business' Edward Lawrence has the very latest there in Washington. Hi, Edward.

EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT: Hey Blake. You know, as you know, economic advisors say that the U.S. has been very specific about what we need to change in terms of trade relationship. Now, the Chinese vice premiere will come to Washington, quote, "soon" to talk with Treasury Secretary Steve Mnuchin in hopes of jump starting talks.

Now he canceled a planned trip for September based on tariffs that the U.S. imposed. White House advisors had a meeting today on trade. China was a focus. It was expected that auto tariffs also came up.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

LARRY KUDLOW, DIRECTOR, NATIONAL ECONOMIC COUNCIL: We are now communicating at all levels. We are working as I say, on background material and preparation. We are waiting for China to come back with some thoughts, and the process is ongoing.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: The U.S. wants to protect intellectual property as well as lower tariffs and increase market access. Right now, some $200 billion in Chinese goods are under a 10 percent tariff. That goes up January 1st to 22 percent tariff. The Chinese are trying to head this off. It could cost more damage to their economy.

Now, another $50 billion of Chinese goods are already under a 25 percent tariff, not to mention steel and aluminum tariffs. We are the Chinese's largest customer. The president creating an incentive possibly for companies to move their supply chain from China to say in Mexico for example, possibly hurting the Chinese economy more.

Now finally, auto tariffs could soon be announced and my trade soruces say that last week, the White House staff circulated a draft of a commerce department section 232 report on auto tariffs. That would be up to 25 percent on autos and then 25 percent or up to 25 percent on auto parts coming into this country.

Although Canada worked out an exemption deal when signing on to the U.S. MCA (ph), but that auto parts really does affect China. They produce a lot of those parts that come into this country. So that could be a further blow if these tariffs go into effect, Blake.

BURNAM: A lot going on, Edward Lawrence, in Washington. Edward, thanks. Meantime, Larry Kudlow also doubled down today on President Trump's use of the phrase nationalist. The president hitting back at Fench President Emmanuel Macron after Macron denounced nationalism in a speech that a host of world leaders attended this past weekend including President Trump. Let's bring in "The Daily Caller" news foundation editor-in-chief, Christopher Bedford. Chris, thanks for joining us.

CHRIS BEDFORD, NEWS FOUNDATION EDITOR-IN-CHIEF, THE DAILY CALLER: Thanks for having me.

BURMAN: Well that went fast with the president and Macron. I mean, there was bromance last year and now not really?

BEDFORD: No, no so much. You can tell if somebody leaves your dinner party and is tweeting about how horrible you are the entire way home that maybe things didn't get off so well. All right, Macron made a mistake I think and a huge over reach here in criticizing the president and using the 100th anniversary to criticize the president.

Of course, nationalism has been largely blamed for a lot of the foolishness that happened at the beginning of World War I and it's a memory, but that does not -- the lesson that you draw from that is not that you don't stand up for your country if you are the elected leader of your country. That's basically your job. Anything else would be considered dereliction of duty. And that's where they're going to hit back on each other here.

BURMAN: Here's what came out of the White House today. You had a tweet from President Trump. He wrote the following. He said, quote, "The problem is that Emmanuel suffers from a very low approval rating in France, 26 percent, and an unemployment rate of almost 10 percent. He was just trying to get on to another subject. By the way, there is no country more nationalist than France. Very proud people and rightfully so."

And then the president goes on to finish that by saying, "Make France great again." Here also was Larry Kudlow on the north lawn of the White House when asked about the bilateral meeting with the president and the French president. Watch it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

KUDLOW: I wasn't there and I wasn't in the (inaudible). As I understand it, I will just say there were pluses and minuses.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BURMAN: Pluses and minuses, how much should we read into this? The fact that the barbs are not happening face to face, it's happening when these two are quite literally in oceans and countries apart? Is this just a meeting and kind of popping off with each other and it will all go into the wayside eventually or is this something serious?

BEDFORD: Well, the president has a good point in that the United States is constantly been the subject of criticism by European countries whether it's civil rights or integration or whether it's over racism or nationalism, and in reality Europe has got an extremely strong and negative history of all those things going on within their borders.

And France in particular suffering with huge issues back and forth between the Catholic Church, between the migrants who have come in and been accepted by France. President Trump worked so hard with personal relationships and he deals so quickly with people who attack him in public.

But he also seems to be quick to forgive. If people say the right word, I mean, look at him and his buddy-buddy relationship with Senator Ted Cruz. They did -- he couldn't get back together with Macron or if Macron says the right things and comes across, I wouldn't read too strong into this fight.

BURMAN: Speaking of relationships, I want to end where we began with China trade. Things are appearing to at least open up. You talked to people at the White House, they say the conversation that the president had with President Xi a couple of weeks ago now really started just kind made things move along the process. Do you anticipate anything to happen down there at the G20 when these two finally meet or are there just too many structural hurdles to still cross at this point?

BEDFORD: I think I anticipate some kind diplomacy and some kind of meetings, but I don't see any massive deal coming too quickly. It's too complicated. It takes too much, but President Trump, one of his first publicly -- longest held public opinions had been that the United States is getting screwed with on trade.

He criticized President Reagan for this, President Bush, President Clinton, President Bush, President Obama. He always said that we're not -- we're getting above and beyond trade. And everyone says you can't mess wit these relationships because it's too delicate. We don't have the power.

Well, right now, China's economy is reeling, the United States economy is heading upwards. So he's not getting a lot of incentive to not demand more from China and say we're going to fix this. It's going top be difficult because China knows they can wait him out.

BURMAN: And speaking of time, the president has got 2019 and 2020 guaranteed. If anything happens with China at all with some sort of a trade deal, is it in 2019, is it in 2020 or is this a long runway at some point?

BEDFORD: I think it certainly a longer runway to get to a solid framework where the United States and China might have base a foundation to be able to move off of, but I would expect concessions long before then. Smaller things, different deals, maybe something on auto parts possibly, although the president knows that's a tool he can wield very effectively against foreign countries.

BURMAN: Chris Bedford, thank you for joining us tonight.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

BURMAN: Appreciate it. Covered a lot of ground. Coming up, first, President Trump says the Europeans should pay their fair share for the fence, it wasn't just Macron today he was taking a shot. Now, Germany's chancellor says maybe they will just create their own European army. The details, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BURMAN: President Trump may have raised a few eyebrows when he called out Europe for what he says is their refusal to pay their fair share for defense -- many countries inside Europe. And now the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, declaring the following saying, "What we should do, and this is really important if we look at the developments over the past yea, we have to work on a vision of one day creating a real true European army." Steve Yates served as the deputy national security adviser under Vice President Dick Chenney and he joins us in studio. Thanks for joining us.

STEVE YATES, FORMER DEPUTY NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER: My pleasure. Thank you.

BURMAN: What do you make of that?

YATES: Well, it's an idea that I think history has heard before and it was -- well, we leave aside the historical irony of the idea, but really this is just an anti-American swipe. We got one major leader of Europe, who is trailing off in Angela Merkel and one in Macron in France who is trying not to trail off.

President Trump has not been shy about giving a jab here or there about their standing on defense issues, pressuring them to pay up on NATO. And so, I don't think this is a serious step by Germany to pay more for defense and take on real threats.

It's more polemics back in forth and it just leaves an old divide between what used to be called old and new Europe, about what their posture is towards Russia and what they are going to pay for their own defense.

BURMAN: If you were advising him on a national security realm considering Angela Merkel only has a few years left, you say Emmanuel Macron us just trying to hold on. You talked about jabbing -- where would you aim those jabs? Would it be at Germany? Would it be at France? Would it be elsewhere? Many people will say why eve jab them at all? They are some of our biggest allies.

YATES: They are allies but some of these alliances need to get prodded every once in a while to step up. And I think some of the people in these countries they want to have economic growth like the United States has. And they might' their country to be more serious about their own defense. And so they face a lot of common challenges with us. I think the president has been right to sort of say, pay up for NATO or what area you going to do?

BURMAN: Here was his tweet today to that effect. The president, again calling out Emmanuel Macron. Here is what he said. He said, quote, "Emmanuel Macron suggest building its own army to protect Europe against the U.S., China and Russia. But it was Germany in World Wars One and Two -- How did that work out for France? They were starting to learn German in Paris before the U.S. came along. Pay for NATO or not."

At the end of the day, is that what the president -- the last part -- is that what he is getting at? He wants these European countries to pay more and to be clear. It's not like NATO itself has a budget that you can cut a check. It is the individual countries themselves have to spend but is that what president really wants.

YATES: It is one of the fundamental plans he campaigned on, rebalancing of some of our alliances and burden sharing. But really, if these leaders were serious about national security, they wouldn't be trying to undermine the sanctions aimed at Iran. They would be doing a little bit more to supor the effort to rebalance the economic relationship and IPR theft with China.

And so we're not having a real conversation about the major geo strategic issues of our time, and that is why I think it is more polemics and I can be -- I can be a little bit guilty of enjoying the snark and the tweets, that's OK too.

BURMAN: You mentioned the major issues of our time. There is going to be a huge summit, the G20 summit in Argentina two and a half weeks from now. Briefly, as Xi Jinping of China is going to be there, Vladimir Putin of Russia is going to be there, in 15 seconds, what do you expecting to come out of that?

YATES: I think it is super important for those relationships to continue, I do not expect major strategic developments. The major rule of thumb is, the more number there are after the G, the less likelihood there is a major breakthrough.

BURMAN: Anything with trade? Anything with Putin?

YATES: There will be a talk about trade, but it's just too short notice and with our politics ramping into reelection, I'd have low expectations for a breakthrough on trade.

BURMAN: Five seconds of goal with Putin is what?

YATES: Goal with Putin is just keep that dialogue going on Middle East and balancing China.

BURMAN: Steven Yates, thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate it. That does it for us tonight on THE EVENING EDIT. Thank you for joining us. And thank you for watching the Fox Business Network. Hopefully Liz MacDonald is back tomorrow. Hope she is feeling well. Lou Dobbs is next.

END

Democratic Congresswoman-Elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Says The $1.5 Billion Tax Break For Amazon In New York Isn't Worth It; Death Toll In California's Deadliest Wildfire Continues To Rise And More Than 200 People Are Still Unaccounted For; Florida's Election Vote Recounts Are Still Ongoing, Along With The Two Candidates, Rick Scott And Bill Nelson Both Filing A Lawsuit; Arizona Has Declared Democrat Kyrsten Sinema As The Winner, And Representative Martha McSally Has Already Conceded Her Defeat; Palmer Luckey's Conservative Political Beliefs Has Him Being Fired From Facebook; A Five-Country International Committee Is Asking Mark Zuckerberg To Appear Before Them But He Is Declining The Invitation; U.S And China Trade Back In Communication On All Levels; Discussion By The Trump Team On Tariffs For European Car Makers; Trump Criticizes France And Europe For Not Paying Fair Share On NATO Defense2018-11-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:09:17ZLexisNexisAmazon Announces That Their Company Will Open Two New Headquarters, One In New York City And The Other In Northern Virginia, The Move Says It Will Bring 50,000 New High-Paying Jobs; Democratic Congresswoman-Elect Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Says The $1.5 Billion Tax Break For Amazon In New York Isn't Worth It; Death Toll In California's Deadliest Wildfire Continues To Rise And More Than 200 People Are Still Unaccounted For; Florida's Election Vote Recounts Are Still Ongoing, Along With The Two Candidates, Rick Scott And Bill Nelson Both Filing A Lawsuit; Arizona Has Declared Democrat Kyrsten Sinema As The Winner, And Representative Martha McSally Has Already Conceded Her Defeat; Palmer Luckey's Conservative Political Beliefs Has Him Being Fired From Facebook; A Five-Country International Committee Is Asking Mark Zuckerberg To Appear Before Them But He Is Declining The Invitation; U.S And China Trade Back In Communication On All Levels; Discussion By The Trump Team On Tariffs For European Car Makers; Trump Criticizes France And Europe For Not Paying Fair Share On NATO DefenseLanhamFULL TEXT

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

DAVID ASMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: And Bart knows it very well, backbone. And I don't think anybody will ever be able to fight it. That does it for Bulls and Bears. Thanks for joining us. "EVENING EDIT" starts now.

BLAKE BURMAN, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK HOST: Amazon Prime for a major east coast move. The online retail giant announcing today it will open not one but two new headquarters, New York and Northern Virginia. A move Amazon says will create 50,000 new and high paying jobs but there are some big reasons why not everyone is happy.

Also, tonight in California, the wildfires there continue to rage. One of the now deadliest ever in that state. We'll bring you the latest from the ground.

Plus, Florida, the recount resumes as the deadline to certify a few statewide contests moves closer.

Republicans trying to flip a Senate seat there after Democrats put an Arizona seat in their win column.

Thank you for joining us tonight. I'm Blake Burman in for Elizabeth MacDonald. THE EVENING EDIT starts right now.

The move so many have been waiting for but with a little bit of a twist today. Amazon announcing that they will open two new headquarters. One in New York City the other in Northern Virginia.

Deirdre Bolton has the very latest this evening. Hi, Deirdre.

(CROSSTALK)

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT: Hey, Blake. Hi. So, this was a long-awaited decision, right, the company choosing Long Island City in Queens, New York, and then the other one in Crystal City area in Arlington, Virginia. So, these two locations chosen after more than a years' long public contest that began with 238 candidate cities.

So, Amazon saying it's going to be investing $5 billion across the two new areas. It's also going to be creating a new operation center in Nashville so completely separate with more than 5000 jobs.

The e-commerce giant saying it went for a split location because it wanted to recruit enough of the best tech talent. Now as part of the contract between Amazon and the two cities they are required to assist Amazon in obtaining a federal approval to build helipad at each location.

Skeptics say those are probably for Amazon's top execs to get in and out of both locations without being slow down by traffic but nonetheless that is part of the deal.

For that reason alone, some locals from some of the other cities that didn't get the nod actually seemed relieved that they took to social media. Comparing notes on the effect that Amazon's main HQ has had on Seattle. Locals of course there complain about skyrocketing rents, prolonged construction and gridlocked traffic.

Other smaller cities have locals that felt burned, in part because local officials had released so much data about their communities to the e- commerce giant.

Even with the recent decline for most tech stocks I want to highlight Amazon still up 40 percent year to date. The NASDAQ up around 4 percent as a comparison point. S&P 500 1.8 percent.

So, Blake, no matter what Amazon is doing year-to-date still a pretty good investment. Back to you.

BURMAN: Yes, one of the best stocks out there, indeed. Deirdre, thank you.

BOLTON: Sure.

BURMAN: Make sure to catch Deirdre's special by the way, Women and Money. It is this Friday at 9.30 Eastern here on the Fox Business Network.

Amazon says that this is a winner. Here's the company's breakdown. It says Virginia stand to receive some $3.2 billion in tax revenue over the next 20 years, with workers averaging over $150,000 a year. Virginia will give Amazon it says $573 million in brakes, 550 million about a cash grant, $23 million comes from the city of Arlington over 15 years for infrastructure projects and the like.

And New York will get $10 billion in tax revenue over the next two decades. So, says Amazon. Again, an average salary of more than $150,000. New York it says will give 1.525 billion in performance-based incentives. Now that's a $1.2 billion refundable tax credit and a cash grant of 325 million for buildings being occupied over the next 10 years so long as they hit those targets.

Not everyone is thrilled with this, as they say there is much more beyond the numbers.

David Dworkin is with the National Housing Conference. He is the CEO of that network and he joins us here in studio. Thanks for joining us.

DAVID DWORKIN, CEO, NATIONAL HOUSING CONFERENCE: Thanks, Blake. Good to be here.

BURMAN: So, when you talk about 25,000 jobs in each one of these major cities each person getting at least $150,000 a year in salary. Some would say what's wrong with that.

DWORKIN: There's nothing wrong with that. It's great news for both communities. The trick is, it needs to stay great news. And the problem that we have to deal with is that when you put that many people into a community at one time over a short period of time you are going to see housing prices go up both for renters and for homebuyers.

And if Amazon's employees can't afford to buy and rent in this community, they are going to end up with the same problem they had in Seattle and they don't want that either.

BURMAN: Deirdre just talked about that. I wanted to get to that in a second. Twenty-five thousand in each city. It's not like all 25,000 are suddenly going to emerge in both of these regions. Some will be from this area. How many do you expect in this greater Washington area and in New York City to suddenly show up there needing a place to live?

DWORKIN: Well, it could be a lot. And it's also already having an impact on pricing. You're seeing condos that were on the market just a few weeks ago. Not getting much action being bid up today and the same things is going to be the case in a little longer time frames with rental properties.

We want to make sure that the development doesn't lead to dislocation. We want people who live in these communities to be able to benefit from this new investment too.

BURMAN: You bring up Seattle. Sky price -- sky -- houses there have skyrocketed. This, speaking of Washington, D.C., has been one of the more stable markets. When it blooms, it doesn't bloom that much, and when it bust, it doesn't bust that much.

This market right here in Northern Virginia, in D.C., Maryland, do you think we could potentially be Seattle part two or three even if you bring New York into the equation?

DWORKIN: Well, we will be if we do it wrong. And the name of the game as we need to be very thoughtful about how we do this development, we need to make sure that we have housing for all incomes because it's all connected.

You talked to people at the White House, they say the conversation that the president had with President Xi a couple of weeks ago now really started just kind made things move along the process. Do you anticipate anything to happen down there at the G20 when these two finally meet or are there just too many structural hurdles to still cross at this point?

BEDFORD: I think I anticipate some kind diplomacy and some kind of meetings, but I don't see any massive deal coming too quickly. It's too complicated. It takes too much, but President Trump, one of his first publicly -- longest held public opinions had been that the United States is getting screwed with on trade.

He criticized President Reagan for this, President Bush, President Clinton, President Bush, President Obama. He always said that we're not -- we're getting above and beyond trade. And everyone says you can't mess wit these relationships because it's too delicate. We don't have the power.

Well, right now, China's economy is reeling, the United States economy is heading upwards. So he's not getting a lot of incentive to not demand more from China and say we're going to fix this. It's going top be difficult because China knows they can wait him out.

BURMAN: And speaking of time, the president has got 2019 and 2020 guaranteed. If anything happens with China at all with some sort of a trade deal, is it in 2019, is it in 2020 or is this a long runway at some point?

BEDFORD: I think it certainly a longer runway to get to a solid framework where the United States and China might have base a foundation to be able to move off of, but I would expect concessions long before then. Smaller things, different deals, maybe something on auto parts possibly, although the president knows that's a tool he can wield very effectively against foreign countries.

BURMAN: Chris Bedford, thank you for joining us tonight.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

BURMAN: Appreciate it. Covered a lot of ground. Coming up, first, President Trump says the Europeans should pay their fair share for the fence, it wasn't just Macron today he was taking a shot. Now, Germany's chancellor says maybe they will just create their own European army. The details, next.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BURMAN: President Trump may have raised a few eyebrows when he called out Europe for what he says is their refusal to pay their fair share for defense -- many countries inside Europe. And now the German Chancellor, Angela Merkel, declaring the following saying, "What we should do, and this is really important if we look at the developments over the past yea, we have to work on a vision of one day creating a real true European army." Steve Yates served as the deputy national security adviser under Vice President Dick Chenney and he joins us in studio. Thanks for joining us.

STEVE YATES, FORMER DEPUTY NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER: My pleasure. Thank you.

BURMAN: What do you make of that?

YATES: Well, it's an idea that I think history has heard before and it was -- well, we leave aside the historical irony of the idea, but really this is just an anti-American swipe. We got one major leader of Europe, who is trailing off in Angela Merkel and one in Macron in France who is trying not to trail off.

President Trump has not been shy about giving a jab here or there about their standing on defense issues, pressuring them to pay up on NATO. And so, I don't think this is a serious step by Germany to pay more for defense and take on real threats.

It's more polemics back in forth and it just leaves an old divide between what used to be called old and new Europe, about what their posture is towards Russia and what they are going to pay for their own defense.

BURMAN: If you were advising him on a national security realm considering Angela Merkel only has a few years left, you say Emmanuel Macron us just trying to hold on. You talked about jabbing -- where would you aim those jabs? Would it be at Germany? Would it be at France? Would it be elsewhere? Many people will say why eve jab them at all? They are some of our biggest allies.

YATES: They are allies but some of these alliances need to get prodded every once in a while to step up. And I think some of the people in these countries they want to have economic growth like the United States has. And they might' their country to be more serious about their own defense. And so they face a lot of common challenges with us. I think the president has been right to sort of say, pay up for NATO or what area you going to do?

BURMAN: Here was his tweet today to that effect. The president, again calling out Emmanuel Macron. Here is what he said. He said, quote, "Emmanuel Macron suggest building its own army to protect Europe against the U.S., China and Russia. But it was Germany in World Wars One and Two -- How did that work out for France? They were starting to learn German in Paris before the U.S. came along. Pay for NATO or not."

At the end of the day, is that what the president -- the last part -- is that what he is getting at? He wants these European countries to pay more and to be clear. It's not like NATO itself has a budget that you can cut a check. It is the individual countries themselves have to spend but is that what president really wants.

YATES: It is one of the fundamental plans he campaigned on, rebalancing of some of our alliances and burden sharing. But really, if these leaders were serious about national security, they wouldn't be trying to undermine the sanctions aimed at Iran. They would be doing a little bit more to supor the effort to rebalance the economic relationship and IPR theft with China.

And so we're not having a real conversation about the major geo strategic issues of our time, and that is why I think it is more polemics and I can be -- I can be a little bit guilty of enjoying the snark and the tweets, that's OK too.

BURMAN: You mentioned the major issues of our time. There is going to be a huge summit, the G20 summit in Argentina two and a half weeks from now. Briefly, as Xi Jinping of China is going to be there, Vladimir Putin of Russia is going to be there, in 15 seconds, what do you expecting to come out of that?

YATES: I think it is super important for those relationships to continue, I do not expect major strategic developments. The major rule of thumb is, the more number there are after the G, the less likelihood there is a major breakthrough.

BURMAN: Anything with trade? Anything with Putin?

YATES: There will be a talk about trade, but it's just too short notice and with our politics ramping into reelection, I'd have low expectations for a breakthrough on trade.

BURMAN: Five seconds of goal with Putin is what?

YATES: Goal with Putin is just keep that dialogue going on Middle East and balancing China.

BURMAN: Steven Yates, thank you so much for joining us. We appreciate it. That does it for us tonight on THE EVENING EDIT. Thank you for joining us. And thank you for watching the Fox Business Network. Hopefully Liz MacDonald is back tomorrow. Hope she is feeling well. Lou Dobbs is next.

END
